snippet: The New York Court of Appeals heard arguments in two murder cases on Tuesday that examined how far police can go in lying to suspects during interrogations.
abstract: New York State Court of Appeals hears arguments in two murder cases that raise question of how far the police can go in lying to suspects during interrogations, such as when police officer’s lies cross a line and become coercion; question has gained attention in legal circles, as more false convictions based on coerced confessions have come to light in high-profile cases.
lead_paragraph: The New York Court of Appeals heard arguments in two murder cases on Tuesday that examined how far police can go in lying to suspects during interrogations.

headline.main: Court Weighs Police Role in Coercing Confessions
headline.print_headline: Court Weighs Police Role In Coercing Confessions
